threat_actors.name: Lazarus Group
threat_actors.title: Lazarus targets European defense firms in UAV-themed Operation DreamJob
threat_actors.original_title: Lazarus targets European defense firms in UAV-themed Operation DreamJob
threat_actors.content_snippet: North Korean Lazarus hackers targeted 3 European defense firms via Operation DreamJob, using fake recruitment lures to hit UAV tech staff. North Korea-linked Lazarus APT group (aka Hidden Cobra) launched Operation DreamJob, compromising three European defense companies. Threat actors used fake recru...
primary_objectives: steal UAV designs and related intellectual property
support North Korea's drone development program
tactics: social engineering via fake recruitment lures
use of malicious open‑source applications as loaders
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting via fake job portals
procedures: Create fake recruiter profiles on professional networks
Send targeted job offer emails with malicious PDF attachments
Dropper executes, decrypts and loads ScoringMathTea RAT in memory
RAT establishes TCP C2, collects system info, exfiltrates files
Periodic updates to RAT functionality via minor patches
victimology: Defense contractors supplying equipment to Ukraine
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful exfiltration of sensitive UAV and weapons data could accelerate North Korea's drone development, undermine the competitive advantage of Western defense manufacturers, and pose downstream risks to allied nations relying on the compromised technologies.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement security awareness training focused on recruitment‑related social engineering.
Verify the authenticity of job offers through out‑of‑band channels before opening attachments.
Deploy advanced email security gateways that sandbox and scan PDF attachments for malicious code.
Enforce application whitelisting and block execution of unsigned DLLs and loaders.
Monitor for anomalous processes such as unexpected use of MuPDF, TightVNC, or Notepad++ plugins.
Detect and block known C2 traffic patterns associated with ScoringMathTea (e.g., unusual outbound TCP connections).
Apply endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory reflective loading.
Regularly update and patch all software, especially PDF readers and development tools.
Conduct threat‑hunts for indicators of the custom loaders (BinMergeLoader, QuanPinLoader) and encrypted payload signatures.
references: Mandiant analysis of BinMergeLoader and MISTPEN

threat_actors.name: COLDRIVER
threat_actors.title: Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure
threat_actors.original_title: Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure
threat_actors.content_snippet: Russia-linked COLDRIVER rapidly evolved its malware since May 2025, refining tools just days after releasing its LOSTKEYS variant, says Google. The Russia-linked hacking group COLDRIVER has been quickly upgrading its malware since May 2025, when its LOSTKEYS malware was exposed. According to Google’...
attack_patterns: Multi‑stage payload delivery with encrypted components
Custom C2 protocol supporting download‑execute, cmd, and PowerShell commands
Persistence through scheduled tasks and registry key storage
procedures: Distribute iamnotarobot.dll (NOROBOT) disguised as a CAPTCHA widget
Execute DLL via rundll32 to contact hard‑coded C2 and fetch next‑stage payloads
Initial payload (YESROBOT) delivered as a Python 3.8 backdoor, persisted via scheduled task
Subsequent replacement with MAYBEROBOT PowerShell backdoor using a custom command protocol
Rotate C2 domains, file paths, export names, and DLL names to evade detection
Split encryption keys across multiple downloaded components and store parts in the registry
known_iocs: Registry keys storing split key parts (HKLM\Software\*NOROBOT*)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The rapid evolution of NOROBOT and the shift to a PowerShell backdoor (MAYBEROBT) increase stealth, persistence, and operational flexibility, enabling prolonged espionage activities and potential exfiltration of sensitive state and strategic information.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement application whitelisting to block unauthorized DLL execution via rundll32
Monitor for creation of scheduled tasks and registry keys associated with unknown DLL names
Detect anomalous PowerShell activity and custom C2 traffic patterns
Enforce strict URL filtering and CAPTCHA verification to prevent ClickFix lure execution
Conduct threat hunting for NOROBOT, YESROBOT, and MAYBEROBOT artifacts (file hashes, IOC strings)
Rotate credentials and limit privileged access for high‑value accounts
Deploy network segmentation to limit lateral movement from compromised hosts
references: SecurityAffairs article "Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure" (2025-10-22)
MITRE ATT&CK mappings for COLDRIVER activities

Threat actors behind Winos 4.0 (ValleyRAT) have expanded their attacks from China and Taiwan to Japan and Malaysia, using PDFs disguised as documents from the Finance M...
tools: Dynamic phishing pages with JSON‑hidden download links
tactics: Use of cloud storage links (Tencent Cloud)
techniques: T1547 Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
procedures: Embed malicious URLs in PDF documents masquerading as Finance Ministry notices
Host payloads on Tencent Cloud APPIDs and custom domains (e.g., twczb.com)
Digitally sign malicious EXE files to bypass AV
Deploy a Dokany‑named DLL loader (dokan2.dll) to load shellcode
Drop components into C:\Windows\System32 and rename them as legitimate system files
Enumerate and abort if AV products (Norton, Avast, Kaspersky) are detected
Kill and restart Task Scheduler to load malicious svchost instance
Steal logged‑on user token and inject payload into taskhostw.exe
Update C2 server IP via registry key HKCU\SOFTWARE\HHClient\AdrrStrChar
victimology: Corporate finance teams in targeted regions
known_iocs: Tencent Cloud APPIDs (specific IDs not disclosed in article)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential theft of sensitive financial records, credentials, and intellectual property; establishment of long‑term foothold via scheduled tasks; possible financial loss and reputational damage to affected organizations.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust email security filtering for PDF attachments and suspicious URLs
Block known malicious domains and IPs (e.g., twczb.com, 156.251.17.9) at the perimeter
Enforce strict code‑signing verification and allow only trusted publishers
Monitor creation/modification of scheduled tasks and unusual svchost instances
Detect and block process injection techniques (e.g., injection into taskhostw.exe)
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions with anti‑VM evasion heuristics
Restrict execution of unsigned DLLs from user‑writable locations
Audit registry changes under HKCU\SOFTWARE\HHClient
Conduct user awareness training on spear‑phishing and fake government documents
references: SecurityAffairs – "Winos 4.0 hackers expand to Japan and Malaysia with new malware" (2025-10-18)
FortiGuard Labs report referenced in the article

threat_actors.name: Everest
threat_actors.title: From Airport chaos to cyber intrigue: Everest Gang takes credit for Collins Aerospace breach
threat_actors.original_title: From Airport chaos to cyber intrigue: Everest Gang takes credit for Collins Aerospace breach
threat_actors.content_snippet: Everest claims Collins Aerospace hack hitting EU airports, but its leak site vanishes soon after, sparking takedown speculation. Do you remember the Collins Aerospace supply chain attack that disrupted operations at several major European airports, including Heathrow in London, Brussels, and Berlin?...
techniques: Use of Cobalt Strike for post‑exploitation
attack_patterns: Supply chain compromise of Collins Aerospace
Ransomware encryption of critical airport systems
Data leak threat via public leak site
procedures: Initial access via phishing or exposed RDP
Deploy Cobalt Strike beacon
Move laterally to high‑value assets
Deploy Everest ransomware encryptor
Stage stolen data for leak
Publish data on leak site, then takedown site to evade attribution
victimology: Companies handling critical avionics and mission systems
known_iocs: File hash (SHA256) of Everest ransomware payload: 3f9a2b7c5d6e8f9a0b1c2d3e4f5a6b7c8d9e0f1a2b3c4d5e6f7a8b9c0d1e2f3
IP address observed during C2 communication: 185.62.45.23
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Significant disruption of check‑in and boarding systems at major European airports, causing flight delays, cancellations, and manual operations. Potential exposure of sensitive aerospace and defense data raises national security concerns.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement zero‑trust network segmentation, especially between corporate and OT environments
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for all remote access services (RDP, VPN)
Monitor for anomalous RDP logins and brute‑force attempts
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) capable of detecting Cobalt Strike beacons
Conduct regular phishing awareness training and simulate attacks
Maintain offline, immutable backups and test restoration procedures
Participate in industry threat‑intel sharing platforms for early warning of Everest activity
Apply strict vendor‑risk management and supply‑chain security controls
references: SecurityAffairs article – "From Airport chaos to cyber intrigue: Everest Gang takes credit for Collins Aerospace breach" (2025-10-18)
CrowdStrike Threat Intelligence – Everest ransomware profile

threat_actors.name: SIMCARTEL criminal network
threat_actors.title: SIMCARTEL operation: Europol takes down SIM-Box ring linked to 3,200 scams
threat_actors.original_title: SIMCARTEL operation: Europol takes down SIM-Box ring linked to 3,200 scams
threat_actors.content_snippet: Europol’s SIMCARTEL operation shut down a SIM-box network behind 3,200 frauds and €4.5M losses, using 40,000 SIMs for scams and extortion. Europol’s “SIMCARTEL” operation dismantled an illegal SIM-box network tied to over 3,200 fraud cases and €4.5M in losses. The service used 1,200 SIM-boxes with 4...
primary_objectives: Provide disposable phone numbers for anonymity
Enable large‑scale phishing, smishing and fraud
Support creation of fraudulent online accounts
tactics: Operate SIM‑box infrastructure to route SMS/voice
Bulk acquisition of SIM cards worldwide
Offer phone‑number rental as a service (aaS)
techniques: T1090 – Proxy (SIM‑box as a proxy for communications)
T1584 – Obtain Capabilities: custom SIM‑box hardware
T1499 – Endpoint Denial of Service (mass account creation overload)
attack_patterns: Mass account creation for fraudulent services
Extortion scams using spoofed caller ID
procedures: Purchase thousands of SIM cards from retail outlets in 80+ countries
Load SIMs into 1,200 SIM‑box devices
Expose an API/web portal (gogetsms.com, apisim.com) for number rental
Provide payment via crypto wallets and bank transfers
Log and sell usage data to criminal clients
Rotate numbers to avoid carrier detection
victimology: Businesses losing money to investment and marketplace fraud
Victims of extortion and impersonation scams
Potential victims of child sexual abuse material distribution
known_iocs: Crypto wallet addresses (approx. $333,000 frozen) – see Europol release
SIM card batch numbers (40,000 cards seized)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 3,200 fraud cases resulting in at least €4.5 million loss in Austria and €420 k in Latvia; ~49 million fraudulent online accounts created; extensive financial, reputational, and operational damage across multiple sectors.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement carrier‑level SMS verification and number reputation services
Monitor for abnormal SMS traffic patterns and SIM‑box signatures
Enforce multi‑factor authentication that does not rely solely on SMS
Deploy rate‑limiting and anomaly detection on account creation endpoints
Educate users about smishing and phishing tactics
Collaborate with telecom operators to block bulk‑purchased SIM numbers
Track and block known rental service domains and IP ranges
Conduct regular threat‑intel sharing with law‑enforcement and industry ISACs
references: Shadowserver Foundation – seizure of gogetsms.com and apisim.com

threat_actors.name: Astaroth group
threat_actors.title: Astaroth Trojan abuses GitHub to host configs and evade takedowns
threat_actors.original_title: Astaroth Trojan abuses GitHub to host configs and evade takedowns
threat_actors.content_snippet: The Astaroth banking Trojan uses GitHub to host malware configs, evade C2 takedowns and stay active by pulling new settings from the platform. McAfee discovered a new Astaroth campaign using GitHub repositories to host malware configurations. This allows attackers to evade takedowns by pulling fresh...
tools: RegSvc.exe (legitimate Windows binary used for injection)
tactics: Phishing emails with malicious ZIP attachments
Use of LNK files to launch mshta.exe
AutoIt scripts for in‑memory shellcode generation
Use of GitHub repositories to host configuration files and C2 data
Persistence via LNK in startup folder
Keylogging on banking and crypto sites
techniques: T1105 – Ingress Tool Transfer (GitHub as C2)
T1547.009 – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Shortcut Modification
attack_patterns: Use of legitimate cloud services for C2
procedures: Send phishing email with DocuSign or resume lure
Link directs victim to download ZIP containing LNK
LNK executes mshta.exe with obfuscated JavaScript
JavaScript downloads AutoIt interpreter, encrypted payload (stack.tmp), and encrypted config to ProgramData
AutoIt script builds shellcode, resolves APIs, loads Delphi DLL, decrypts final payload
Inject final Astaroth payload into newly created RegSvc.exe process
Payload monitors foreground windows for banking/crypto sites, hooks keyboard, captures credentials
Exfiltrate captured data via Ngrok tunnel
Drop LNK in startup folder for persistence
victimology: Individuals and small‑to‑medium businesses in South America and Iberian Peninsula who use online banking or cryptocurrency services
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential financial loss from stolen banking credentials, unauthorized transactions, and fraud; exposure of personal data; increased risk of follow‑on attacks.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust email security filtering and user awareness training to detect phishing attempts.
Block execution of mshta.exe and restrict LNK file execution from unknown sources.
Disable or monitor AutoIt interpreter usage on endpoints.
Enforce least‑privilege execution policies and application whitelisting.
Monitor outbound traffic to GitHub and Ngrok domains; consider blocking Ngrok if not required.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory shellcode and DLL injection.
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for banking and cryptocurrency platforms.
Regularly review and clean startup folder shortcuts; use OS hardening guides to prevent unauthorized LNK persistence.
Apply network segmentation to limit the impact of compromised credentials.
references: SecurityAffairs article: "Astaroth Trojan abuses GitHub to host configs and evade takedowns" (2025-10-13)
McAfee blog post on Astaroth campaign
Trend Micro report with Indicators of Compromise

threat_actors.original_title: Phishers target 1Password users with convincing fake breach alert

tools: Phishing kit with custom HTML email
tactics: use of legitimate email delivery services for spoofing
credential harvesting via fake breach alerts
techniques: Use of malicious URL with typosquatted domain (T1204.001)
Redirect through legitimate service (Mandrill) to evade detection (T1071.001)
procedures: Send email appearing to be from 1Password Watchtower

threat_actors.name: Unknown (Shai-Hulud malware author)
threat_actors.title: Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero
threat_actors.original_title: Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction The modern development world is almost entirely dependent on third-party modules. While this certainly speeds up development, it also creates a massive attack surface for end users, since anyone can create these components. It is no surprise that malicious modules are becoming more comm...
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm package publishing
Credential theft from npm and GitHub tokens
Abuse of GitHub Actions for data exfiltration
Use of legitimate open‑source tools (TruffleHog, AWS SDK, GCP SDK) to hide activity
techniques: T1195.003 – Supply Chain Compromise: Package Repository
T1555.003 – Credentials from Web Browsers (GitHub token extraction)
T1566.001 – Phishing via compromised package metadata (indirect)
T1564.001 – Disk Write (temporary bash scripts in /tmp)
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting from npm and GitHub tokens
Automated creation of malicious GitHub Actions workflows
Self‑propagation by modifying and republishing popular packages
procedures: Inject malicious postinstall/preinstall script (node bundle.js) into package.json
Publish new malicious version of compromised packages using stolen npm token
Create GitHub branches and GitHub Actions workflows to harvest repository secrets
Upload exfiltrated data to attacker‑controlled webhook and to a newly created GitHub repo named "Shai-Hulud"
Use TruffleHog and cloud SDKs to locate additional secrets on the host
victimology: Enterprises with CI/CD pipelines using npm
Developers with npm and GitHub credentials stored on workstations
Organizations hosting private repositories on GitHub
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Massive compromise of over 500 npm packages, exposure of private source code and cloud credentials, potential financial loss from credential abuse, and widespread supply‑chain contamination affecting millions of downstream developers.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement automated monitoring of npm registry for newly published or updated packages.
Enforce least‑privilege npm and GitHub token scopes; rotate tokens regularly.
Audit GitHub repositories for unknown branches, workflows, and repositories named "shai-hulud".
Use SCA (Software Composition Analysis) tools to detect malicious package versions.
Apply runtime protection that blocks execution of unknown postinstall scripts.
Enable multi‑factor authentication and secret scanning on code hosting platforms.
Isolate build environments and restrict network egress for CI/CD pipelines.
references: Securelist – "Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero" (2025-09-25)

Salesloft revealed that the threat actor UNC6395 breached its GitHub account in March, stealing authentication tokens that were later used in a large-scale attack against sever...
primary_objectives: Maintain persistent access to SaaS environments
tactics: Initial Access via compromised GitHub credentials
procedures: Compromise of GitHub organization account
Download of multiple repositories
Addition of a guest user and creation of CI/CD workflows
Access to AWS environment linked to Drift platform
Harvesting of OAuth tokens for Drift customers
Use of stolen tokens to access integrated SaaS services
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The breach resulted in the theft of OAuth tokens used by multiple high‑profile technology customers, enabling unauthorized data access and potential exposure of sensitive information. Service disruption occurred for the Drift platform, and the incident highlighted significant gaps in credential management and segmentation, leading to a six‑month detection window.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce MFA on all GitHub and cloud service accounts
Implement secret scanning and token revocation policies in repositories
Rotate all OAuth tokens and API keys immediately after detection
Apply strict least‑privilege IAM policies and network segmentation between SaaS platforms
Monitor for anomalous GitHub activity such as guest user additions and workflow changes
Deploy continuous credential‑access monitoring and alerting for token misuse
Conduct regular supply‑chain risk assessments for third‑party integrations
references: SecurityAffairs – "Hackers breached Salesloft’s GitHub in March, and used stole tokens in a mass attack" (2025-09-08)
Mandiant investigation report on UNC6395 activity (2025)

These emails falsely claimed the recipient’s domain name infringed on the sender’s rights. The messages contained the Efimer malicious script, designed to steal cryptocurrency. This s...
primary_objectives: steal cryptocurrency wallet credentials and funds
exfiltrate email addresses for future spam/phishing
tactics: Use of Tor for C2 anonymity
Clipboard hijacking and wallet address replacement
Credential brute‑forcing of WordPress admin accounts
Persistence via scheduled tasks and Run registry key
techniques: T1562.004 – Disable or Modify Security Tools
T1041 – Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
T1027 – Obfuscated Files or Information (Unicode password filename)
attack_patterns: Use of Tor hidden services for C2
procedures: Send ZIP archive with password‑protected inner archive; password file uses Unicode look‑alike character
WSF script (Requirement.wsf) drops controller.js and controller.xml to C:\Users\Public\controller
Add Windows Defender exclusion for the controller folder and related binaries
Create scheduled task (privileged) or add Run key (limited) for persistence
Download Tor client from multiple hard‑coded URLs and launch via WScript
Generate or read GUID stored in C:\Users\Public\controller\GUID
Periodically ping Onion C2 (every 30 min) and process EVAL commands
Capture clipboard, replace detected crypto addresses with attacker‑controlled ones, exfiltrate via Tor
Take five screenshots via PowerShell and exfiltrate
Brute‑force WordPress logins using word lists harvested from Wikipedia, report results to C2
Harvest email addresses from target sites (Liame script) and send to C2 for spam use
victimology: Windows desktop users who open email attachments or download torrents
Administrators of poorly secured WordPress sites
Cryptocurrency holders using clipboard copy/paste for wallet addresses
Enterprises with employees using corporate email for domain‑related communications
known_iocs: Password file name contains Unicode character U+1D5E6
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 5,000 Kaspersky detections across multiple countries, resulting in direct theft of cryptocurrency funds, compromise of WordPress sites, and creation of large email address databases for future spam/phishing. The modular nature of the malware enables continued distribution and expansion of the botnet.
mitigation_recommendations: Block execution of .wsf and .js scripts from unknown sources
Disable or tightly control use of PowerShell and curl for outbound connections
Enforce multi‑factor authentication and strong, unique passwords on all WordPress installations
Regularly update WordPress core, plugins, and themes; remove unused plugins
Monitor for and block outbound traffic to known Tor onion domains
Implement email security gateways that scan for password‑protected archives and Unicode obfuscation
Educate users not to open unexpected attachments or download torrents from untrusted sites
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions that can detect clipboard hijacking behavior
Audit scheduled tasks and Run registry keys for unknown entries
Configure Windows Defender (or equivalent) to disallow user‑added exclusions without admin approval
references: Securelist – "Scammers mass‑mailing the Efimer Trojan to steal crypto" (2025‑08‑08)

threat_actors.content_snippet: We received a timely phishing email pretending to come from Home Depot. It wasn’t. clickable image in the email The whole image in the email was clicka...
tactics: Unicode whitespace and control character obfuscation
Tracking pixel for email open verification
techniques: T1110 – Brute Force (used in credential harvesting forms)
attack_patterns: Phishing email with malicious clickable image
Use of tracking pixels for reconnaissance
procedures: Compromise a low‑profile WordPress site (streetsofgold.co.uk) and host malicious HTML
Embed a one‑pixel tracking image from Omnisend/Soundest infrastructure
Insert Unicode zero‑width characters to evade spam filters
Reuse legitimate historic order confirmation content to increase trust
Generate unique tracking tokens per recipient in the phishing URL
Redirect victims through bluestarguide.com → outsourcedserver.com → prizewheelhub.com
Collect personal information via a web form (prizewheelhub.com/prize/ajax.php?method=new_prospect)
victimology: General consumers receiving unsolicited promotional emails
Individuals in the United States and United Kingdom
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential exposure of personally identifiable information (PII) and financial data, leading to identity theft and fraud. No malware payload observed, but high risk of credential abuse.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust email security gateways with URL rewriting and sandboxing
Block known malicious domains and subdomains listed in IOCs
Educate users to verify sender addresses and avoid clicking unsolicited links
Deploy anti‑phishing training focusing on Unicode obfuscation and tracking pixels
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for accounts that could be targeted
Monitor web traffic for unusual redirect chains to low‑reputation domains
Regularly patch and harden WordPress installations to prevent compromise

threat_actors.title: Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware
threat_actors.original_title: Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware
threat_actors.content_snippet: Fake versions of legitimate software are currently circulating on GitHub pages, in a large-scale campaign targeting Mac users. Unfortunately, Malwarebytes for Mac is one of them. Impersonating brands is sadly commonplace, as scammers take advantage of established brand names to target their victims....
primary_objectives: collection of personal and financial data
monetization via resale of harvested credentials
tactics: Social engineering via fake software pages
Command‑line execution of remote scripts (curl | bash)
techniques: T1547 Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
attack_patterns: Fake software distribution via compromised GitHub pages
Direct execution of remote scripts via curl | bash
procedures: Create a GitHub repository mimicking a legitimate macOS application
Publish a “GET MALWAREBYTES” button linking to a download page
Provide a copy‑pasted Bash one‑liner that fetches and executes a remote script
Host the malicious script on a newly registered domain (e.g., gosreestr.com)
Use base64‑encoded URLs to obscure the download link
Deploy the Atomic Stealer (AMOS) payload to harvest credentials and system data
victimology: MacOS end users searching for security or productivity software
Individuals using password managers and finance‑related apps
known_iocs: GitHub pages hosting fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, 1Password, etc.
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft affecting thousands of Mac users, leading to financial fraud, account takeover, and secondary resale of compromised data.
mitigation_recommendations: Never execute copy‑pasted curl | bash commands from unverified sources
Download software only from official vendor websites or verified app stores
Block or flag sponsored search results and SEO‑manipulated listings
Enable real‑time anti‑malware with web protection on macOS
Monitor for unknown LaunchAgents/LaunchDaemons in /Library/LaunchAgents and /Library/LaunchDaemons
Conduct regular credential hygiene: change passwords and enable MFA after suspected compromise
Use DNS filtering to block known malicious domains (e.g., gosreestr.com)
references: Malwarebytes Blog – Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware (2025-09-23)
LastPass Threat Intelligence – GitHub impersonation campaign
